{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=July 2017}} {{essay-like|date=April 2017}} }}
'''Environmental health policy''' is the interplay between the [[Natural environment|environment]] and [[health]], and how the environment can affect human health. Policies are created by governments and organizations where they see the issues arising in the health of their jurisdiction related to the environment.
There are several environmental factors that can contribute to health including air quality, [[climate change]], toxic drinking water, and toxic chemical exposure.<ref name=":24">{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Kirk|last2=Corvalan|first2=Carlos|last3=Kjellstrom|first3=Tord|year=1999|title=How Much Global Ill Health Is Attributable to Environmental Factors?|url=|journal=Epidemiology Research Inc.|volume=10|pages=|via=}}</ref> Depending on the region the policy is in, different environmental factors are going to be addressed in the policy. Some effects of the environment on health can include [[asthma]], [[malaria]], [[cholera]], disease, [[cancer]], and physical injury.<ref name=":24" /> These are also dependent on the area in which the individual lives, and how severe the environmental factors are. Climate change issues have become more prevalent in the 21st century, requiring action from global leaders. When there are substantial changes to the environment, a populations health is vulnerable to potential risks.
Environmental health policy can be implemented at many levels of government, including the municipal, state and international levels.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Investing Together: Working Effectively Across Levels of Government|last=OECD|first=|publisher=OECD Publishing|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Municipal governments focus on [[Public policy|policies]] that affect the boundaries they control, while state governments focus on several cities or states within their borders where environment affects health. International policies involve the cooperation of several states to implement the same policy to address larger environmental issues on health like pollution and climate change.
[[Developing country|Developing nations]] take a different approach to environmental health politics than [[Developed country|developed nations]]. Developing nations do not always have the same access to resources to implement policies that can improve the environment and health of their citizens.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Conteh|first=Charles|last2=Ohemeng|first2=Frank|year=2009|title=The Politics of Decision Making in Developing Countries|url=|journal=Public Management Review|volume=11|pages=57–77|via=}}</ref> Environmental factors can have an unequal effect on lower income and ethnic minority regions being exposed to environmental stressors and a lower quality of life.
== Definition == Environmental Health Policy is the combination between the environment and the health of citizens in a defined area.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dummer|first=Trevor|year=2008|title=Health geography: supporting public health policy and planning|url=|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|volume=178|pages=1177–80|via=}}</ref> When defining Environmental Health policy it is best to break down the concept into three separate groups: [[Natural environment|environment]], health and policy. The environment aspect of the term refers to the ecosystems and the environmental factors that can affect human health.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buhrs|first=Ton|last2=Bartlett|first2=Robert|year=1991|title=Environmental Policy in New Zealand|url=|journal=The Politics of Clean and Green|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> [[Health]] refers to the human beings ability to function successfully when environmental factors are constantly changing.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Huber|first=Machteld|last2=Knottnerus|first2=J. André|last3=Green|first3=Lawrence|last4=Horst|first4=Henriëtte van der|last5=Jadad|first5=Alejandro R.|last6=Kromhout|first6=Daan|last7=Leonard|first7=Brian|last8=Lorig|first8=Kate|last9=Loureiro|first9=Maria Isabel|date=2011-07-26|title=How should we define health?|url=http://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d4163|journal=BMJ|language=en|volume=343|pages=d4163|doi=10.1136/bmj.d4163|issn=0959-8138|pmid=21791490}}</ref> In its more simplistic definition, health is the overall well-being of a person.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=World Health Organization|first=|year=2006|title=Constitution of the world Health Organization|url=|journal=Basic Documents|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> [[Policy]] is a "course of action or principle adopted or proposed by a government, party, business, or individual".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Concise Oxford Dictionary|last=|first=|publisher=1995|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Environmental Health Policy refers to the [[human impact on the environment]], which in turn affects human health and requires policy action.
== Environmental Factors == One environmental factor that contributes to the health of the global community is [[climate change]]. Climate change is the long term rising and/or dropping of temperatures and the deviation of weather patterns over time.<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Forman|first=Gideon|year=2015|title=Climate Change Already Makes Us Sick|url=|journal=Alternatives Journal|volume=41|pages=|via=}}</ref> As a result of climate change, the Canadian Arctic has increased in temperature by three or four degrees.<ref name=":18" /> As the warming of the Northern Arctic continues, a surplus of water enters the system. Whether the surplus is due to rain or melting snow, an increased amount of [[pathogen]]s enter the fresh water.<ref name=":18" />
With increasing weather extreme trends, [[Vector (epidemiology)|vector]] and [[Waterborne diseases|water-borne diseases]], as well as allergies become more prevalent in these conditions.<ref name=":19">{{Cite journal|last=Patz|first=Jonathan|last2=Campbell- Lendrum|first2=Diarmid|last3=Holloway|first3=Tracey|last4=Foley|first4=Jonathan|year=2005|orig-year=|title=Impact of Regional Climate Change on Human Health|url=|journal=Nature|volume=438|pages=310–317|via=}}</ref> These infectious diseases and what accompanies them (mosquitoes, tics etc.) rely upon the environment to spread and survive.<ref name=":19" /> The reproduction and spread of these diseases are severely affected by weather fluctuations.<ref name=":19" />
Air pollution is another environmental factor that has been proven to be an influence on health. Air pollution has become a more serious issue in recent years as developing nations are experiencing a high [[birth rate]] and low [[Mortality rate|death rate]]. The more people that are in these regions means the more resources required to sustain them. Air pollution comes in two forms; emission and transmission. These pollutants come from various sources, such as modes of transportation, the burning of fossil fuels, or naturally from the ground.
[[Sea level rise|Rising sea levels]] is another environmental factor that affects the health of individuals in a given region. One of the reasons why sea levels begin to rise is due to the melting of large glacier ice.<ref name=":20">{{Cite journal|last=Milne|first=Glenn|date=2008-04-01|title=How the climate drives sea-level changes|url=https://academic.oup.com/astrogeo/article/49/2/2.24/246715/How-the-climate-drives-sea-level-changes|journal=Astronomy & Geophysics|volume=49|issue=2|pages=2.24–2.28|doi=10.1111/j.1468-4004.2008.49224.x|issn=1366-8781}}</ref> If the glacier icecaps start melting faster, sea levels will be affected.<ref name=":20" /> Another way that the sea levels rise is when temperatures increase, the water molecules expands and require more space.<ref name=":20" /> As sea levels start to rise, the shore line starts to expand. In serious situations, this causes people to become environmental refugees. As the sea level rises it starts to affect valuable land used for food and other harvesting. 200 million people is the amount of people that are at risk of flooding should the sea level rise 40 cm by the 2080s.<ref name=":19" />
== Health Risks == The health risks that are a result of the environment are starting to affect people around the globe. It is estimated that the increasing temperatures over the past 30 years have resulted in the deaths of 150,000 lives each year.<ref name=":19" /> Europe in the summer of 2003 experienced higher than normal temperatures resulting in the deaths of approximately 22,000 to 45,000 in the span of two weeks.<ref name=":19" /> This has been the worst effect of climate change in recent history. Increasing rates of extreme temperature are directly related to increased mortality. Some of the health risks that come with extreme temperatures are heat stress, cardio vascular failure, Hypothermia, etc.<ref name=":19" />
The temperature affects the malaria parasites in the mosquitoes and its ability to incubate as well as how likely the mosquitoes are to [[Hematophagy|blood feed]].<ref name=":21">{{Cite journal|last=Kigozi|first=Ruth|last2=Zinszer|first2=Kate|last3=Mpimbaza|first3=Arthur|last4=Sserwanga|first4=Asadu|last5=Kigozi|first5=Simon P.|last6=Kamya|first6=Moses|date=2016-01-01|title=Assessing temporal associations between environmental factors and malaria morbidity at varying transmission settings in Uganda|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1186/s12936-016-1549-2|journal=Malaria Journal|volume=15|pages=511|doi=10.1186/s12936-016-1549-2|issn=1475-2875|pmc=5070351|pmid=27756304}}</ref> Mosquitoes thrive in the transmission of parasites where temperatures do not exceed 25 degrees Celsius.<ref name=":21" /> Excessive rain, which is becoming more frequent amongst many countries, acts as the perfect breeding site for the aquatic beginning of a mosquito's life.<ref name=":21" /> Malaria is a vector- borne disease that is extremely prevalent in Africa. The disease puts billions of people at risk of contracting the virus.<ref name=":21" /> Due to a lack of sufficient healthcare where the disease is most concentrated, many people die.<ref name=":19" /> The environment is a huge contributor to the success malaria has in transmitting the disease.<ref name=":21" />
One of the more common health risks that people encounter is a result of air pollutants and air quality. Allergic [[Asthma]] is a chronic disease that affects individual's inflammatory system when they are exposed to allergens resulting in shortness of breath, wheezing, and coughing.<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Mukherjee|first=Anil B.|last2=Zhang|first2=Zhongjian|date=2011-09-23|title=Allergic Asthma: Influence of Genetic and Environmental Factors|url=http://www.jbc.org/content/286/38/32883|journal=Journal of Biological Chemistry|language=en|volume=286|issue=38|pages=32883–32889|doi=10.1074/jbc.R110.197046|issn=0021-9258|pmc=3190897|pmid=21799018}}</ref> Environmental factors such as, air pollutants, tobacco smoke, emission fumes, and other allergens in the air when absorbed through the body are said to have an influence on allergic asthma.<ref name=":22" />
Climate change can affect humans' respiratory health by aggravating respiratory disease or increasing exposure to potential risks of the disease.<ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=D’Amato|first=Gennaro|last2=Cecchi|first2=Lorenzo|last3=D’Amato|first3=Mariella|last4=Annesi-Maesano|first4=Isabella|date=2014-06-01|title=Climate change and respiratory diseases|url=http://err.ersjournals.com/content/23/132/161|journal=European Respiratory Review|language=en|volume=23|issue=132|pages=161–169|doi=10.1183/09059180.00001714|issn=0905-9180|pmid=24881071}}</ref> Climate change can affect the respiratory system by the amount of pollen and allergens in the air, mold proliferation, and the effects of the ozone layer.<ref name=":23" /> The increase of temperatures results in putting a strain on the respiratory system often causing asthma and other lung diseases.<ref name=":23" /> Some of the health risks that are closely related to the respiratory system are asthma, rhnosinusitis, respiratory tract infections, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.<ref name=":23" />
== Perspectives ==
=== Municipal level ===
==== Hamilton, Ontario (Canada) ==== The Hamilton steel mill region has had higher levels of air pollution than the rest of the city. The effect of air pollution in the region has resulted in the spending of $537 million per year on health care and other associated costs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jerrett|first=Michael|year=2001|title=A GIS- environmental justice analysis of particulate air pollution in Hamilton, Canada|url=|journal=Environment and Planning|volume=33|pages=955–973|via=}}</ref> Many health issues that arise with air pollution in Hamilton is premature death, respiratory problems, and cardiovascular problems. Hamilton is taking the initiative to spread awareness around environmental issues with the implementation of yearly summits.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hamilton Environmental Summit 2013 (City Wide)|last=Murray|first=Chris|publisher=City of Hamilton|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Vision 2020 is a community based development program which encourages community reporting of environmental issues, which influences policy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wakefield|first=Sarah|last2=Elliott|first2=Susan|last3=Cole|first3=Donald|year=2007|title=Social capital, environmental health and collective action: a Hamilton, Ontario case study|url=|journal=The Canadian Geographer|volume=51|pages=428–443|via=}}</ref>
==== Rochester, New York (United States of America) ==== In 2005, the city of Rochester enacted a rental housing-based lead law when the incidence of childhood lead poisoning was rising.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Korfmacher|first=Katrina|last2=Ayoob|first2=Maria|last3=Morley|first3=Rebecca|year=2012|title=Rochester's Lead Law: Evaluation of a Local Environmental Health Policy Innovation|url=|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|volume=120|pages=|via=}}</ref> The new amendment to the housing code requires a lead inspection of rental properties built before 1978, with a focus on deteriorating paint within and outside the house.<ref name=":5" /> The law requires property owners to remove any lead based paint and dust from the premise and obtain a certificate of occupancy before they are able to rent out the property again.<ref name=":5" /> In order to keep compliance with the law, Rochester allows owners to be trained in lead safe repair work so [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] workers are not required to correct violations.<ref name=":5" />
==== Harlem, New York (United States of America) ==== Harlem, along with many areas of the United States, have taken on a community based participatory research method to examine environmental health policy.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Vasquez|first=Victoria|last2=Minkler|first2=Meredith|year=2006|title=Promoting Environmental Health Policy Through Community Based Participatory Research: A Case Study from Harlem, New York|url=|journal=Journal of Urban Health|volume=83|pages=|via=}}</ref> The [[West Harlem Environmental Action|West Harlem Environmental ACTion Inc.]] and Columbia University's Centre for Children's Environmental Health studied the effects of [[diesel exhaust|diesel pollution]] on the environment, and provided the results to the government, which transformed their environmental health policies to accommodate the results.<ref name=":4" /> Respiratory health was the main concern for the policy change, which was traced back to particular matter and carbon within local diesel sources.<ref name=":4" /> Harlem reconstructed their bus fleet system by using clean diesel and installation of permanent air monitors to control the amount of air pollution created by buses.<ref name=":4" />
==== Sao Paulo, Brazil ==== The metropolitan area of São Paulo has dealt with issues of air and water pollution created by motor vehicles and inadequate treatment of sewage.<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Stephens|first=Carolyn|last2=Akerman|first2=Marco|last3=Maia|first3=Paulo|year=1995|title=Health and Environment in Sao Paulo, Brazil: Methods of Data Linkage and Questions of Policy|url=|journal=World Health Statistics Quarterly|volume=48|pages=|via=}}</ref> Infectious and parasitic diseases, circulatory diseases, and respiratory problems have all been a concern in São Paulo.<ref name=":17" /> The city uses data linkages (HEADLAMP) between the environment and health in order to influence future policies. [[Pollution|Air pollution]] has been improved marginally in regards to industrial pollution, but motor vehicle traffic creates the largest amount of sulphur dioxide emissions.<ref name=":17" /> Water treatment plants have not grown to accommodate the growing population, but piped water and sanitation facilities have been expanding.<ref name=":17" /> Impacts of the environment on health have been felt more in the poorer areas of the city compared to the wealthier sectors.<ref name=":17" />
=== State level ===
==== Developed nations ====
===== Canada ===== Canada has dealt with [[Lead poisoning|lead exposure]] for decades, decreasing since the 1970s with the phasing out of [[lead paint]] and gasoline.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=The Environment and Health: An Introduction for Nurses|last=|first=|publisher=Canadian Nurses Association|year=2007|isbn=978-1-55119-214-7|location=Ottawa, ON|pages=}}</ref> While there has been a decrease in lead poisoning, there is still cases of exposure to lead from paint and old pipes in homes.<ref name=":3" /> Lead exposure is more harmful for pregnant women and children, making them more prone to poisoning. Lead was listed as a toxic substance under the Canadian Environmental Protection Act.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/toxiques-toxics/Default.asp?lang=En&n=98E80CC6-1&xml=D048E4B9-B103-4652-8DCF-AC148D29FB7D|title=Lead|last=Government of Canada|first=|date=2014|website=Environment and Climate Change Canada|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The government implemented regulations against lead to foster a healthy environment.
The First Nations and Inuit Health Branch attempts to ensure that these communities are given equal access to health services comparable to those in similar locations of Canada.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|title=First Nations Environmental Public Health Program|last=Minister of Health|first=|publisher=Health Canada|year=2008|isbn=978-0-662-48257-4|location=Ottawa: ON|pages=}}</ref> [[Health Canada]] defines a health environment to include safe water, food, maintained housing and facilities, disposal of waste, and the ability to prevent and control disease.<ref name=":12" /> The Environmental Public Health Program is implemented in several aboriginal communities, customized to specific needs including [[food security]], clean water sources, and improving poor housing conditions.<ref name=":12" />
===== United States ===== The United States has several policies to deal with chemical exposure, air quality, energy, oil pollution, and safe drinking water. Public exposure to chemicals can have effects on the body including cancer, cardiovascular disease, asthma and obesity.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Shibley|first=G|year=2014|title=Using Law and Policy to Address Chemical Exposures: Examining Federal and State Approaches|url=|journal=Capital University Law Review|volume=42|pages=97–141|via=}}</ref> Those who work in industrial and agriculture sectors are more prone to exposure, but children, pregnant women, and those with chronic medical conditions are also at a higher risk of exposure.<ref name=":15" /> The United States has implemented the [[Toxic Substances Control Act of 1976|Toxic Substances Control Ac]]t to deal with chemical exposure and ensure chemicals are safe and citizens are minimally affected.<ref name=":15" />
The EPA is developing clean diesel fuels and biodiesel to deal with air pollution caused by motor vehicle emissions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Nexus of Biofuels, Climate Change, and Human Health|last=Pool|first=Robert|publisher=National Academies Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-29241-2|location=Washington, DC|pages=}}</ref> These types of emissions can affect respiratory health, risk of cancer, and increased medical costs of the population. In 2013, transportation was more than half on carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides produced in the environment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucsusa.org/clean-vehicles/vehicles-air-pollution-and-human-health#.WNx-jlK-KCQ|title=Vehicles, Air Pollution, and Human Health|last=|first=|date=n.d.|website=Union of Concerned Scientists|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The country has also implemented vehicle emission standards to cut pollution from motor vehicles.
===== Norway ===== Norway has several environmental regulations dealing with pollution, air quality, and water.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Norway Environment, Health & Safety Profile and Checklist|last=|first=|publisher=The Isosceles Group|year=2014|isbn=|location=Boston|pages=}}</ref> There are also policies in place to protect citizen's health and well-being in general, and in the workplace.<ref name=":1" /> Workplaces must ensure they have measures to prevent or contain pollution, along with voluntarily preparing environmental impact statements that are available to pollution control authority.<ref name=":1" /> If facilities produce carbon dioxide emissions, then they must apply for a discharge permit, and have to report yearly emissions to pollution control authorities.<ref name=":1" /> Norway attempts to protect its water sources from contamination by ensuring facilities implement measures that cause the least amount of harm or inconvenience to the public or corporations.<ref name=":1" /> The government puts policies in place to ensure the safety of employee health at all levels, and takes action on any hazards within the workplace that would put health at risk.<ref name=":1" />
===== Turkey ===== Air quality in Turkey is currently at levels that are considered harmful to human health. Lung capacity growth of children is diminished in areas of high air pollution, which can increase chances of [[Respiratory disease|lung disease]].<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Air Pollution and Health in Turkey: Facts, Figures and Recommendations|last=|first=|publisher=The Health and Environmental Alliance|year=2015|isbn=|location=Brussels, Belgium|pages=}}</ref> Risks to lung health include asthma, [[Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease]], lung cancer, and emphysema which can be intensified by poor air quality.<ref name=":6" /> Coal power in Turkey has been a critical factor of air pollution.<ref name=":6" /> The power plants release [[sulfur dioxide]], [[nitrogen oxide]]s, and [[Mercury (element)|mercury]], which can last in the environment for up to forty years.<ref name=":6" /> The Turkish Medical Association expressed concerns about increasing the amount of [[Fossil fuel power station|coal plants]] in Turkey, and suggested a phasing out of coal plants to increase air quality in the country to safe levels.<ref name=":6" />
===== Germany ===== The Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Health have coordinated with agencies and scientific institutions to understand environmental health issues.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Forbat|first=Julien|year=2015|title=Environmental Health Policies in Europe: Successes and Failures in Switzerland, Germany, and Belgium|url=|journal=International Journal of Environment and Health|volume=7|pages=|via=}}</ref> Germany has had a long history of environmental health policies in order to maintain the well being of citizens.<ref name=":13" /> Policies are based on scientific research and collaboration between ministries, but environmental health policies are often not on the policy agenda since it is relatively well controlled.<ref name=":13" />
In 2011, policies were adopted to phase out [[Nuclear power|nuclear energy]] in the country after [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|Fukushima nuclear disaster]].<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=http://www.azocleantech.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=549|title=Germany: Environmental Issues, Policies and Clean Technology|last=Smith|first=Brett|date=2015|website=AZO Cleantech|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Air pollution increased to the highest levels since the 1980s due to increased coal burning, putting the population at risk for chronic diseases associated with air pollution.<ref name=":14" /> Mining in the country had also resulted in water pollution that affects human and animal health.<ref name=":14" /> Coal mining has been linked to environmental and health issues, leading the government to close all mining pits by 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/the-rise-and-fall-of-germanys-coal-mining-industry/a-2331545|title=The Rise and Fall of Germany's Coal Mining Industry|last=|first=|date=2007|work=Deutsche Welle|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Germany has been a leading actor in dealing with carbon emissions related to climate change through policies to reduce use of resources and efficient use of [[Renewable energy|renewable energy sources]].<ref name=":14" />
==== Developing nations ==== ===== China ===== China has large-scale mineral resources and is one of the biggest producers and consumers of metals and metalloids.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=Zhiyuan|last2=Ma|first2=Zongwei|last3=Jan van der Kuijp|first3=Tsering|last4=Yuan|first4=Zengwei|last5=Huang|first5=Lei|year=2013|title=A review of soil heavymetal pollution from mines in China: Pollution and health risk assessment|url=|journal=Science of the Total Environment|volume=468|pages=843–853|via=}}</ref> Since the 1980s, they have seen an increase in pollution and degradation of [[natural resource]]s, putting the health of the population at risk. Air pollution is the biggest environmental cause of [[Pulmonary heart disease|cardiopulmonary disease]] in the country.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Choi|first=Kyungho|last2=Paek|first2=Domyung|last3=Wu|first3=Tangchun|last4=Chan|first4=Chang-Chaun|last5=Onchang|first5=Rattapon|last6=Padungtod|first6=Chantana|last7=Koizumi|first7=Akio|year=2012|title=Asian Forum on Environmental Health Policy: Challenges and Perspectives of Environmental Health Problems in the Region for the Next 30 Years|url=|journal=Environmental Health and Preventative Medicine|volume=17|pages=170–172|via=}}</ref> The Asian countries are looking to research environmental factors to better understand how it affects health.
China's mines have produced heavy metal polluted soils that pose a risk to human health.<ref name=":2" /> Those living around the area of the mines are especially at risk of the [[carcinogen]]ic and non-carcinogenic risks of the soil. The main dangers come from sewage irrigation, sludge application, mining, and smelting operations.<ref name=":2" /> This pollution affects the human body by harming the nervous, skeletal, circulatory, enzymatic, endocrine, and immune system.<ref name=":2" /> More chronic effects can include cancer, bone fractures, hypertension, lesions, and neuropathy.<ref name=":2" /> China has conducted very few health risk assessment studies of all mines in the country, so full health risks associated with the mines are unknown.
===== India ===== In the mining communities of India, the population is at risk of respiratory illness and malaria.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Saha|first=Shubhayu|last2=Pattanayak|first2=Subhrendu|last3=Sills|first3=Erin|last4=Singha|first4=Ashok|year=2011|title=Under-mining health: Environmental justice and mining in India|url=|journal=Health and Place|volume=17|pages=140–148|via=}}</ref> Those who live closer to the mines reported higher incidences of these illnesses. This has influenced environmental policy because mining is a profitable business that can be privatized, but with adverse effects on health they have been required to balance human and ecological health.<ref name=":10" />
India has also seen difficulty providing access to drinking water and sanitation services in rural areas.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Pattanayak|first=Subhrendu|last2=Poulos|first2=Christine|last3=Yang|first3=Jui-Chen|last4=Patil|first4=Sumeet|year=2010|title=How valuable are environmental health interventions? Evaluation of water and sanitation programmes in India|url=|journal=Bull World Health Organ|volume=88|pages=535–542|via=}}</ref> [[Community-driven development|Community demand-driven programmes]] have been implemented since 2004 which required improvements in water supply, sanitation, and hygiene.<ref name=":11" /> This was an effort to improve children's health, and reduce diarrhoea and water-related illnesses.<ref name=":11" /> Only 21% of the rural population was using a private tap, the other percentage commuted to obtain water. Only 12% used private toilets, the others travelled to a main sanitation site.<ref name=":11" /> The implemented program was able to increase access to filtered water, private toilets, and increased hygiene.
===== Nigeria ===== In 2014, Nigeria implemented the WHO Country Cooperation Strategy to deal with Millennium Development Goals. A strategic objective of the policy was to assess health effects of environmental risks by conducting health impact assessments.<ref name=":16">{{Cite book|title=WHO Country Cooperation Strategy 2014-2019|last=WHO Regional Office for Africa|first=|publisher=|year=2014|isbn=978 92 9 023207 0|location=Nigeria|pages=}}</ref> The government also plans to increase countries abilities to deal with environmental emergencies including climate change, air pollution, and radiation that could be harmful to health.<ref name=":16" /> The strategy focuses on creating policies to improve medicine, [[Universal health care|universal access to health care]], and reduction in diseases caused by the environment.<ref name=":16" />
===== Kenya ===== In 2016, the Kenya government introduced the new Kenya Environmental Sanitation and Hygiene Policy.<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title=Kenya environmental Sanitation and Hygiene Policy|last=Ministry of Health|first=|publisher=Republic of Kenya|year=2016|isbn=|location=Nairobi, Kenya|pages=}}</ref> Poor sanitation has been a leading cause of mortality in the country. The new policy created a timeline from 2016-2030 in which guidelines were set for state and non-state actors to follow to improve sanitation and create a better quality of life.<ref name=":7" /> The aim is to have universal access to [[sanitation]] by 2030. This includes all public places and dwellings having access to sustainable toilets, free from odours, and reducing hygiene related diseases.<ref name=":7" /> Currently, about 72% of toilets in rural Kenya are dug pits and open defecation occurs. The amount of sanitation sewers is very low, with most not being treated.<ref name=":7" /> Sewage bursts and discharge of raw sewage from plants is a common practice, contaminating the earth and water supply.<ref name=":7" /> Air pollution in urban centres is also a concern. In Nairobi, pollution levels are three times higher than World Health Organization recommendations.<ref name=":7" /> [[Urbanization]] is projected to increase in the next decade, so the government has created [[Kenya Vision 2030]] in attempts to deal with sanitation practices in the country.<ref name=":7" /> Kenya Visions wants to make Kenya a newly industrialized, middle-income country with a high quality of life for its citizens.<ref name=":7" />
=== International level === ==== World Health Organization (WHO) ==== In 2006, the [[World Health Organization]] created a study on specific diseases and injuries affected by environmental risks, and which regions of the world are at the most risk of injury.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Preventing Disease Through Healthy Environments: Towards an Estimate of the Environmental Burden of Disease|last=Pruss-Ustun|first=A.|last2=Corvalan|first2=C.|publisher=World Health Organization|year=2006|isbn=92 4 159382 2|location=Switzerland|pages=}}</ref> WHO studies the effects and supports the design of preventative and health strategies in countries to reduce environmental health risks.<ref name=":0" /> Environmental factors such as air and water quality, patterns of energy use, and patterns of land use can directly and indirectly affect health of citizens.<ref name=":0" /> WHO's findings found that 24% of global disease and 23% of deaths are caused by environmental factors (although they vary from developing countries with 25%, and developed with 17%).<ref name=":0" /> Several diseases found in the study included [[Diarhhea|diarrhea]], respiratory infections, malaria, and unintentional injuries caused by environmental factors that can be modified by policy.<ref name=":0" /> Infectious diseases is a higher burden in developing countries than in developed, attributed to more exposure to environmental risks and lack of access to health care.<ref name=":0" /> Diseases attributed to environmental factors decrease with development to either eradication, or to levels comparable to developed regions.<ref name=":0" /> Children are disproportionately affected by environmental hazards. WHO found that children under the age of five are more prone to diseases from environmental factors than the rest of the total population.<ref name=":0" />
WHO has supported the United Nation's Millennium Development Goals to provide sustainable access to safe drinking water. The benefits to the MDG's is savings in health care, economic productivity, and fewer lives lost from diseases caused by contaminated water.<ref name=":0" />
==== United Nations ==== In 2000, the [[Millennium Development Goals]] (MDG) were created at the UN Millennium Declaration. Leaders from all over the world gathered in aims to reduce poverty by 2015 in developing countries.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=B|last2=Taylor|first2=S|year=2017|title=Squaring the circle: health as a bridge to global solidarity in the Sustainable Development Goals|url=|journal=Archives Disease Child|volume=0|pages=1–4|via=}}</ref> Eight goals were created in order to deal with extreme poverty due to climate, shelter, and disease, and ensure everyone has the right to health, education, shelter, and security.
[[Sustainable Development Goals]] (SDG) were created to replace the MDG, which are to be reached by 2030. These goals are aimed at both developing and developed countries, using environmental, social, and economic dimensions to meet goals.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Abel|first=Guy|year=2016|title=Meeting the Sustainable Development Goals leads to lower world population growth|url=|journal=PNAS|volume=113|pages=|via=}}</ref> Goals 3, 6, and 11 affect environmental health policy. Goal 3 is to ensure good health and well-being, which affects other goals. If environmental goals are achieved, the health of the country will be able to improve by reducing disease and death.<ref name=":8" /> Goal 11 of creating sustainable cities and communities is important to environmental health policy since urbanization is a big concern that can affect resources including water, which affects the health of the population.<ref name=":9" /> Goal 6 aims to provide clean water and sanitation in countries.<ref name=":9" /> Wastewater treatment in countries is an issue that the SDG goals are trying to influence countries to improve and provide better access to clean drinking water and sanitation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Malik|first=Omar|last2=Hsu|first2=Angel|last3=Johnson|first3=Laura|last4=Sherbinin|first4=Alex|year=2015|title=A global indicator of wastewater treatment to inform the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)|url=|journal=Environmental Science and Policy|volume=48|pages=172–185|via=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|3}}
[[Category:Environmental health]] [[Category:Environmental policy]]

revision.text:
'''Ethnic media''' is media fashioned with a particular [[ethnic minority]] group or ethnic minority community in mind.
== Definition == Academic Yu Shi tenders an operational definition for ethnic media: “Ethnic media are often regarded as media ''by and for'' ethnics in a host country with content in ethnic languages."<ref>Shi, Yu. (2009, p. 599). Re-evaluating the 'alternative' role of ethnic media in the US: the case of Chinese-language press and working-class women readers. Sage Publications.</ref> Shi also adds, ethnic media “can be published by big ethnic media groups and by small organic ethnic communities”, as well.<ref>Shi, Yu. (2010). Audio Interview.</ref>
Practitioner Inga Buchbinder of New America Media adds, “Our organization defines it most as a publication, whether that’s news, television, radio, online, print, magazine--any sort of publication that caters to a specific ethnic community. And it could be in-language…or it could be bilingual that reaches a very specific community.”<ref>Buchbinder, Inga. (2010). Audio Interview.</ref>
In addition to news, television, radio, online, print, and magazine outlets that qualify as ethnic media, academic John D.H. Downing adds musical culture and forms of religious expression to the ethnic media mix. Downing finds, “these may, along with language and dialect, act as a media force somewhere between shock absorption and psychic validation in the often fraught atmosphere between the ethnic majority and ethnic minorities.”<ref>Downing, John. (2001, p. 82). Radical Media: Rebellious communication and social movements. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.</ref>
Downing finds that ethnic media tends to circulate, “within at least three different sectors, namely, indigenous nations and communities, recent migrants…and settled subordinate ethnic groups.”<ref>Downing, John. (2001, p. 81). Radical Media: Rebellious communication and social movements. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.</ref>
== Ethnic media as alternative media ==
Analogous to the debate as to ''what'' qualifying factors constitute [[alternative media]], the domain of ''what'' qualifying factors that classify a respective ethnic media outlet as an alternative media outlet is also, at play.
Thus, ethnic media is not by definitional default alternative media.
Again, the work of academics and grassroots practitioners, such as John D.H. Downing, Yu Shi, Clemencia Rodriguez, and Inga Buchbinder of New America Media provide definitional assistance for this complex and overdetermined zone. Discernment of whether or not a respective ethnic media outlet qualifies as an alternative media outlet is dependent upon the outstanding contextual information, and should be assessed on a case by case evaluation.
Yu Shi’s work puts forth a seven-pronged test for evaluating the “alternative media role” of ethnic media in the United States: “reference has to be made to their (1) individual place of origin, (2) historical evolution, (3) production process, (4) distribution pattern, (5) ownership, (6) self-identity (non-profit or for-profit; alternative or commercial; or in between), and (7) connection to power groups in local and transnational settings.”<ref>Shi, Yu. (2009, p. 600). Re-evaluating the 'alternative' role of ethnic media in the US: the case of Chinese-language press and working-class women readers. Sage Publications.</ref>
== Examples of ethnic media == *[[Black Enterprise|''Black Enterprise Magazine'']] *[[Black Entertainment Television]] *[[Ebony (magazine)|''Ebony'']] *[[Essence magazine|''Essence Magazine'']] *''[[Jet Magazine]]'' *[[Latina magazine|''Latina Magazine'']] *[[Telemundo|Telemundo Television Network]] *[[Univision|Univision Television Network]] *[[My own media]] *[[I-Italy]] *[[Italian American Voice]] *[[Jewish Daily Forward]]
== Examples of ethnic alternative media == *''[[Chicago Defender]]'' *''[[Freedom's Journal]]'' *[[Pittsburgh Courier|''New Pittsburgh Courier'']] *[[North Star (anti-slavery newspaper)|''North Star'']] *''[[Philadelphia Tribune]]'' *''[[The New York Amsterdam News]]''
== See also == *[[abolitionism|The Abolitionist Movement]] *[[Black power|The Black Power Movement]] *[[Clemencia Rodriguez]] *[[Citizen media|Citizens' Media]] * [[German American journalism]] * [[Irish American journalism]] *[[John DH Downing]] *[[New America Media]] *[[United States home front during World War II#African American: Double V campaign|The Pittsburgh Courier's Double V Campaign]]
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Jaroszyńska-Kirchmann, Anna D. ''The Polish Hearst: Ameryka-Echo and the Public Role of the Immigrant Press'' (University of Illinois Press, 2015) * Johnson, Melissa A. "How ethnic are US ethnic media: The case of Latina magazines." ''Mass Communication & Society'' 3#2-3 (2000): 229-248. * Kent, Robert B., and Maura E. Huntz. "Spanish-language newspapers in the United States." ''Geographical Review'' (1996): 446-456. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/215508 in JSTOR] * Ma, Yan. "Chinese American newspapers and periodicals in the United States and their web presence." ''Serials Review'' 29#3 (2003): 179-198. * Mahtani, Minelle. "Representing minorities: Canadian media and minority identities." ''Canadian ethnic studies'' 33#3 (2001): 99-133. [http://canada.metropolis.net/events/ethnocultural/publications/mahtani_e.pdf online] * Miller, Sally M., ed. ''The ethnic press in the United States: A historical analysis and handbook'' (Greenwood, 1987) [https://www.questia.com/read/29031418/the-ethnic-press-in-the-united-states-a-historical online] * Ogunyemi, Ola, ed. ''Journalism, audiences and diaspora'' (Palgrave Macmillan, 2015) * Prentoulis, Marina. "The construction of the black British community in The Voice and the New Nation." ''Journalism'' 13#6 (2012): 731-749. * Pride, Armistead Scott, and Clint C. Wilson. ''A history of the Black press'' (Howard University Press, 1997) * Razi, Alpen. "'Coloured Citizens of the World': The Networks of [[Empire loyalism]] in Emancipation-Era Jamaica and the Rise of the Transnational Black Press." ''American Periodicals: A Journal of History, Criticism, and Bibliography'' 23#2 (2013): 105-124. * Thomas, Eric. "Canadian broadcasting and multiculturalism: Attempts to accommodate ethnic minorities." ''Canadian Journal of Communication'' 17.3 (1992). [http://cjc-online.ca/index.php/journal/article/view/676/582 online] * Viswanath, Kasisomayajula, and Pamela Arora. "Ethnic media in the United States: An essay on their role in integration, assimilation, and social control." ''Mass Communication & Society'' 3#1 (2000): 39-56.
== External links == *[http://henryjenkins.org/2009/03/can_african-americans_find_the.html/ Can African-Americans Find Their Voice in Cyberspace?: A Conversation with Dayna Cunningham (Part One of Four)] *[http://henryjenkins.org/2009/03/can_african-americans_find_the_1.html/ Can African-Americans Find Their Voice in Cyberspace?: A Conversation with Dayna Cunningham (Part Two of Four)] *[http://henryjenkins.org/2009/03/can_african-americans_find_the_2.html/ Can African-Americans Find Their Voice in Cyberspace?: A Conversation with Dayna Cunningham (Part Three of Four)] *[http://henryjenkins.org/2009/03/can_african-americans_find_the_3.html/ Can African-Americans Find Their Voice in Cyberspace?: A Conversation with Dayna Cunningham (Part Four of Four)]
{{Ethnicity}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ethnic Media}} [[Category:Mass media]] [[Category:Cultural media]] [[Category:Ethnic media| ]]

revision.text:
{{original research|date=July 2016}} '''Gender pay gap in India''' refers to the difference in earnings between women and men in the paid employment and labor market.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dutta|first=Puja|date=2005|title=Accounting for Wage Inequality in India|url=http://www.isleijle.org/ijle/IssuePdf/d7ce3acf-12eb-4ead-932a-f8de5bf31ead.pdf|journal=The Indian Journal of Labour Economics|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> For the year 2013, the [[gender pay gap]] in India was estimated to be 24.81%.<ref name="wageindicator">{{cite web|title=Gender Pay Gap in the Formal Sector: 2006 - 2013(September, 2013)|url=http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/publicationslist/publications-2013/gender-pay-gap-in-formal-sector-in-india-2006-2013|publisher=Wage Indicator Data Report}}</ref> Further, while analyzing the level of female participation in the economy, this report slots India as one of the bottom 10 countries on its list. Thus, in addition to unequal pay, there is also unequal representation, because while women constitute almost half the Indian population (about 48% of the total), their representation in the work force amounts to only about one-fourth of the total.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eleventh Five Year Plan (2007-2012) Planning Commission, Government of India|url=http://planningcommission.nic.in/plans/planrel/11thf.htm}}</ref>
== History and contributing factors ==
The female labor participation rate in India from 1901 to 1951 was between 28 and 34 percent, which is higher than the level of participation observed in 1990.<ref name="LSE">{{cite web|url=http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/6641/1/Gender_Discrimination_and_Growth_Theory_and_Evidence_from_India.pdf|title=Gender Discrimination and Growth: Theory and Evidence from India (January, 2004)|date=2004|publisher=London School of Economics|last1=Esteve-Volart|first1=Berta}}</ref> This rate also varies from state to state. Regions in northern India (which have been observed to be more patriarchal) have lower participation rates for women than the states in southern India, where women have more freedom to participate in the formal economy.<ref name="LSE" /> [[Self Employed Women's Association|SEWA]] (the Self Employed Women’s Association) recently found that the average wage of women workers was Rs. 1815 while the average wage for men was Rs. 3842.
Some of the main factors that contribute to the existing gender pay gap in India are:
===Occupational segregation=== The rate of female participation in the paid labor market is generally low, and is primarily concentrated in rural areas in the agricultural sector.<ref name="IMF" /> In rural north India, it has been observed that labor is divided sharply on the basis of gender. Certain activities in agriculture have been assigned specifically to women, like drying and storing the grain, while other tasks like plowing and harvesting are only performed by men.<ref name="Chen">{{cite web|last1=Martha C. Nussbaum, Jonathan Glover|first1=Martha Chen|title=Women, Culture, and Development: A Study of Human Capabilities|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jhLgdK84Ll8C&lpg=PP1&pg=PA37#v=onepage&q=india&f=false|publisher=Clarendon Press|date=1995}}</ref><ref name="justjobs">{{cite web|last1=Dewan|first1=Sabina|title=Closing the Gender wage gap in Indian Agriculture|url=http://justjobsnetwork.org/wp-content/pubs/reports/8.pdf|publisher=JustJobs Network|date=2014}}</ref> Female labor participation in India has been observed to be higher in sectors involving personal services and care work, and is also higher in informal sectors, especially in agriculture.<ref name="Status of Women" />
===Cultural barriers=== While social and cultural norms vary from state to state within India, one commonality that has been observed is the exclusion of women from the paid labor market and status based segregation of labor.<ref name="Chen" /> Ironically, women from higher castes faced more difficulty when they tried to obtain paid work, even if their survival depended on it.<ref name="Chen" />{{Rp|45}} In interviews conducted with widows from rural North India, they stated that if attempts were made to seek gainful employment outside their homes, they would be forced to give up their property rights and made to leave the villages they live in, indicating that paid work was not a feasible option even to sustain themselves due to the existing [[Norm (social)|social norms]].<ref name="Chen" />{{Rp|49}} Because childcare is viewed primarily as a woman's job, women often take part-time jobs or take time off during their careers to care for their families. When women return to work after a break, they are paid lower wages than their male colleagues. Women employed full-time ordinarily already earned 34% less than men, but when compared to part-time working women, the pay gap further increased as they earned almost 42% less than men.<ref name="wageindicator finalreport">{{cite web|url=http://www.paycheck.in/files/gender-pay-gap-oct-2012-1|title=Gender Pay Gap in the Formal Sector: Preliminary Evidence from Paycheck India Data|date=September 2012|publisher=WageIndicator Data Report|last1=Leeja Anand|first1=Biju Varkkey, Rupa Korde,}}</ref>{{Rp|13}} Additionally, even if women do not have children, it has been observed that they still face pay discrimination as they are viewed as potential mothers, who may require a break from work in the near future.<ref name="wageindicator finalreport" />
===Education and training=== The literacy rate for women in India is far lower than the rate for men, and it has been observed that many girls drop out of school and fail to fully complete their education.<ref name="Status of Women" />{{Rp|76}} Investment in education and training has also been strongly in favor of men as they are brought up with the expectation of being bread earners, and hence this investment is considered necessary for their success, while women are instead viewed as "future homemakers" for whom education may not be as essential.<ref name="Understanding GI">{{cite web|last1=Rustagi|first1=Preet|title=Understanding Gender Inequalities in Wages and Incomes in India|url=http://www.isleijle.org/ijle/IssuePdf/6d6c974d-9da9-4a33-a6d0-1a2e193d58e0.pdf|publisher=The Indian Journal of Labour Economics, Vol. 48, No. 2|date=2005}}</ref>{{Rp|325}}
===Unpaid work=== According to the [[Human Development Report]] 1995, women spend about two-thirds of their working time on unpaid work, while men spend only one-fourth of their time towards unpaid labor.<ref name="invisible heart">{{cite web|title=The Invisible Heart— Care and the Global Economy|url=http://akgul.bilkent.edu.tr/hdr/1999/en/pdf/hdr_1999_ch3.pdf}}</ref> It has been estimated in India that women on average work twenty-one more hours than men during each week.<ref name="invisible heart" /> Agriculture currently accounts for over two-thirds of the current employment in India, but most of the work women contribute to this sector is not accounted for or officially documented.<ref name="Status of Women">{{cite web|last1=Anil Kumar Mishra|first1=Tauffiqu Ahamad, Jitendra Kumar Pandey,|title=The Status of Women Workers in the Unorganized Sector|url=http://www.newmanpublication.com/admin/issue/br/Untitled3.pdf|publisher=Newman International Journal of Multidisciplinary Studies, Volume 1, Issue 12|pages=72–79|date=December 2014}}</ref>
== Legislative protections ==
===International obligations=== India has been a permanent member of the [[International Labour Organization|ILO]] Governing Body from 1922. In September 1958, India ratified the C100 Equal Remuneration Convention, 1951 (No. 100), which addressed the issue of equal pay between men and women for work of equal value.<ref>{{cite web|title=C100 - Equal Remuneration Convention, 1951 (No. 100), Article 1|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=NORMLEXPUB:12100:0::NO::P12100_INSTRUMENT_ID:312245}}</ref> This convention requires all member states to direct their national laws and policies towards guaranteeing equal remuneration to all workers, regardless of gender. In an attempt to ensure compliance with this convention and in response to the [[Towards Equality|Report]] by the Committee on status of women in India, the government enacted the Equal Remuneration Act.<ref name="Chapter2">{{cite web|title=Equal Pay for Equal Work in India - A Socio-legal Imperative|url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/28562/9/09_chapter%202.pdf}}</ref>
=== Equal Remuneration Act, 1976 === In 1976, the Equal Remuneration Act was passed with the aim of providing equal remuneration to men and women workers and to prevent discrimination on the basis of gender in all matters relating to employment and employment opportunities. This legislation not only provides women with a right to demand equal pay, but any inequality with respect to recruitment processes, job training, promotions, and transfers within the organization can also be challenged under this Act.<ref>{{cite web|title=Section 4 and 5, Equal Remuneration Act, 1976 |url=http://pblabour.gov.in/pdf/acts_rules/equal_remuneration_act_1976.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421031623/http://pblabour.gov.in/pdf/acts_rules/equal_remuneration_act_1976.pdf |archivedate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref> However, its scope does not extend to situations where: (i) a woman is attempting to comply with the requirements of laws giving women special treatment; and (ii) a woman is being accorded special treatment on account of the birth of a child, or the terms and conditions relating to retirement, marriage or death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Section 15, Equal Remuneration Act, 1976 |url=http://pblabour.gov.in/pdf/acts_rules/equal_remuneration_act_1976.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421031623/http://pblabour.gov.in/pdf/acts_rules/equal_remuneration_act_1976.pdf |archivedate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref> Companies and individual employers can both be held accountable to maintain the standards prescribed under this Act.<ref>{{cite web|title=Section 11, Equal Remuneration Act, 1976 |url=http://pblabour.gov.in/pdf/acts_rules/equal_remuneration_act_1976.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421031623/http://pblabour.gov.in/pdf/acts_rules/equal_remuneration_act_1976.pdf |archivedate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref> In various cases, the [[Supreme Court of India]] has also held that discrimination on the basis of gender only arises when men and women perform the same work or work of a similar nature. However, it clarified that a flexible approach is required to be taken while deciding which kinds of work may be similar by considering the duties actually performed as a part of the job, and not the duties potentially capable of being performed.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Mackinnon Mackenzie & Co. Ltd. v. Audrey D’ Costa & Another|journal=(1987) 2 SCC 469}}</ref>
=== Constitutional protections === As part of its [[Directive Principles in India|Directive Principles of State Policy]], the [[Constitution of India]] through Article 39 envisages that all states ideally direct their policy towards securing equal pay for equal work for both men and women, and also ensuring that men and women have the right to an adequate means of livelihood. While these [[Directive Principles in India|Directive Principles]] are not enforceable by any court of law, they are crucial to the governance of the country and a state is duty bound to consider them while enacting laws.<ref name="Myth">{{cite book|last1=Devi|first1=Kovuru|title=Women's Equality in India: A Myth Or Reality?|date=January 1, 2000|isbn=81-7141-563-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LS8wJlfjUcUC&printsec=copyright#v=onepage&q&f=false|pages=49–50}}</ref>
While “equal pay for equal work” is not expressly a constitutional right, it has been read into the [[Constitution of India|Constitution]] through the interpretation of Articles 14, 15 and 16 – which guarantee equality before the law, protection against discrimination and equality of opportunity in matters of public employment.<ref name="Myth"/><ref>{{cite web|title=The Constitution of India, Articles 14 - 16 |url=http://lawmin.nic.in/coi/coiason29july08.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140909230437/http://lawmin.nic.in/coi/coiason29july08.pdf |archivedate=2014-09-09 |df= }}</ref> The [[Supreme Court of India]] has also declared this to be a constitutional goal, available to every individual and capable of being attained through the enforcement of their fundamental rights set out in Articles 14 through 16.<ref>{{cite book|title=Union of India v. Dineshan K.K.,|publisher=(2008) 1 SCC 586}}</ref> In a popular [[Supreme Court of India|Supreme Court]] decision, the conditions of employment of the air-hostesses of Air India was challenged. The terms of employment required the mandatory retirement of females: (i) upon attaining the age of 33; (ii) if they were married within four years of service; or (iii) upon their first pregnancy. The court however struck down these provisions and held them to be arbitrary and discriminatory as it violated Articles 14, 15 and 16 of the Constitution.<ref>{{cite book|title=Air India vs. Nargesh Mirza,|publisher=AIR 1981 SC 1829}}</ref>
=== Ancillary legislation === While legislation like the Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 and the Factories Act, 1948 do not directly address the issue of equal pay for equal work, they provide certain additional benefits a woman can claim. The Maternity Benefit Act applies to all establishments with more than ten employees.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 (Act No. 53 of 1961), Section 2|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/travail/docs/678/maternitybenefitsact1961.pdf}}</ref> However, in states where the Employees’ State Insurance Act applies, employers no longer have any liability under the Maternity Benefit Act.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Papola|first1=T.S.|title=An Assessment of the Labour Statistics System in India, 2014|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---asia/---ro-bangkok/---sro-new_delhi/documents/publication/wcms_342333.pdf|publisher=International Labour Organization}}</ref> Under this Act, a pregnant woman worker is entitled to 12 weeks of fully paid maternity leave, and six weeks in case of miscarriage or termination of pregnancy.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 (Act No. 53 of 1961), Section 4 and 6|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/travail/docs/678/maternitybenefitsact1961.pdf}}</ref> Pregnant women also have the right to not perform physically arduous work, which may affect their pregnancy, and no deductions can be made from their wages because of this.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 (Act No. 53 of 1961), Sections 4 and 13|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/travail/docs/678/maternitybenefitsact1961.pdf}}</ref> Additionally, as per the Factories Act, employers are required to provide childcare for children under 6 years old at all worksites that employ over 30 women.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Factories Act, 1948 (Act No. 63 of 1948), Section 48|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/travail/docs/663/}}</ref>
== Statistics ==
=== By state === The gender pay gap varies across Indian states, and is the highest in the following states:<ref name="wageindicator" /> {| class="wikitable" |- ! State !! Women's earnings as a percentage of men's earnings |- | [[Bihar]] || 63% |- | [[Chhattisgarh]] || 48% |- | [[Assam]] || 48% |- | [[Himachal Pradesh]] || 45% |- | [[Rajasthan]] and [[Kerala]] || 44% |}
[[Uttarakhand]] on the other hand is the state with the lowest percentage of gender pay gap, with females earning only 9% less than men. [[Punjab]] and [[Uttar Pradesh]] are also states with a lower gender pay gap, following with 10% and 15%, respectively.<ref name="wageindicator" />
=== By education === The gender pay gap in India increases with an increase in educational qualifications. While comparing men and women who had only completed high-school level education, it was observed that women earned 10.34% less than men.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} Women who had gone to college for four to five years or who had received advanced degrees earned around 30% less than their male counterparts. With an increase in the level of education, where women had obtained a [[Master's degree]] of a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D]] equivalent, it was observed that the gender pay gap ranged between 44% to 46%.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}}
== Impact == Research suggests that when countries are able to raise the female labor participation rate, this stands to benefit the entire economy.<ref name="IMF">{{cite web|last1=Staff Discussion Note|first1=IMF|title=Women, Work, and the Economy: Macroeconomic Gains from Gender Equity|url=https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/sdn/2013/sdn1310.pdf|publisher=International Monetary Fund|date=September 2013}}</ref> Apart from potential [[GDP]] growth, equal employment opportunities for women could also result in increased growth and profitability in the private sector.<ref name="IFC">{{cite web|title=Investing in Women’s Employment|url=http://www.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/5f6e5580416bb016bfb1bf9e78015671/InvestinginWomensEmployment.pdf?MOD=AJPERES|publisher=International Finance Corporation, World Bank Group|date=2013}}</ref> In countries where the population is aging quickly, an increase in the female labor participation rate would help offset the negative effects of a declining workforce.<ref name="IMF" /> It is also important to note that women in India perform 9.8 times the amount of labor in the unpaid sector either through household duties or care work. If this work was measured and valued, it was estimated by [[McKinsey & Company|McKinsey]] that it would contribute 0.3 trillion dollars to India’s total economic output.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Power of Parity: Advancing Women’s Equality in India|journal=McKinsey Global Institute|date=November 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Equal pay for equal work]] *[[Gender discrimination in India]] *[[Gender inequality in India]] *[[Gender pay gap]] *[[Indian labour law|Indian labor law]] *[[Labour in India|Labor in India]] *[[Social issues in India]] *[[Women in India]]
== Notes == {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Gender in India]] [[Category:Labour in India]] [[Category:Gender pay gap|India]] [[Category:Gender inequality by country|-India]] [[Category:Income in India]]

page.title: History of women in the United Kingdom

revision.text:
'''History of women in the United Kingdom''' covers the social, cultural and political roles of women in Britain over the last two millennia. [[File:Suffragette1913.jpg|thumb|right|upright|300px|Cover of WSPU's ''The Suffragette'', April 25, 1913]]
==Medieval== {{main|Women in the Middle Ages|Anglo-Saxon women}} [[File:Hunterian Psalter c. 1170 Eve spinning.jpg|thumb|upright|left|A depiction of an English woman c. 1170 using a [[Spindle (textiles)|spindle]] and [[distaff]], while caring for a young child]] Medieval England was a [[Patriarchy|patriarchal society]] and the lives of women were heavily influenced by contemporary beliefs about gender and authority.<ref>{{citation | last = Mate | first = Mavis E. | contribution = Introduction | editor-last = Mate | editor-first = Mavis | title = Trade and economic developments, 1450-1550: the experience of Kent, Surrey and Sussex | pages = 2–7 | publisher = Boydell Press | location = Woodbridge, UK Rochester, New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 9781843831891 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Mate | first = Mavis | contribution = Overseas trade | editor-last = Mate E. | editor-first = Mavis | title = Trade and economic developments, 1450-1550: the experience of Kent, Surrey and Sussex | pages = 97–99 | publisher = Boydell Press | location = Woodbridge, UK Rochester, New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 9781843831891 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> However, the position of women varied according to factors including their [[social class]]; whether they were unmarried, married, widowed or remarried; and in which part of the country they lived.<ref>{{citation | last = Johns | first = Susan M. | contribution = Power and portrayal | editor-last = Johns | editor-first = Susan M. | title = Noblewomen, aristocracy, and power in the twelfth-century Anglo-Norman realm | page = 14 | publisher = Manchester University Press | location = Manchester New York | year = 2003 | isbn = 9780719063053 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Henrietta Leyser argues that women had much informal power in their homes and communities, although they were of officially subordinate to men. She identifies a deterioration the status of women in the Middle Ages, although they retained strong roles in culture and spirituality.<ref>{{cite book | last = Leyser | first = Henrietta | title = Medieval women: a social history of women in England, 450-1500 | publisher = Phoenix Giant | location = London | year = 1996 | isbn = 9781842126219 }}</ref>
Significant gender inequities persisted throughout the period, as women typically had more limited life-choices, access to employment and trade, and legal rights than men. After the Norman invasion, the position of women in society changed. The rights and roles of women became more sharply defined, in part as a result of the development of the feudal system and the expansion of the English legal system; some women benefited from this, while others lost out. The rights of widows were formally laid down in law by the end of the twelfth century, clarifying the right of free women to own property, but this did not necessarily prevent women from being [[Forced marriage|forcibly remarried]] against their wishes. The growth of governmental institutions under a succession of bishops reduced the role of queens and their households in formal government. Married or widowed noblewomen remained significant cultural and religious patrons and played an important part in political and military events, even if chroniclers were uncertain if this was appropriate behaviour. As in earlier centuries, most women worked in agriculture, but here roles became more clearly gendered, with [[ploughing]] and managing the fields defined as men's work, for example, and [[Dairy farming|dairy production]] becoming dominated by women.<ref>{{citation | last = Mate | first = Mavis E. | contribution = Trade within and outside the Market-Place | editor-last = Mate | editor-first = Mavis | title = Trade and economic developments, 1450-1550: the experience of Kent, Surrey and Sussex | pages = 21–27 | publisher = Boydell Press | location = Woodbridge, UK Rochester, New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 9781843831891 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Johns | first = Susan M. | title = Noblewomen, aristocracy, and power in the twelfth-century Anglo-Norman realm | pages = 22–25, 30, 69, 195–96 14 | publisher = Manchester University Press | location = Manchester New York | year = 2003 | isbn = 9780719063053 }}</ref>
In medieval times, women had responsibility for brewing and selling the ale that men all drank. By 1600, men had taken over that role. The reasons include commercial growth, gild formation, changing technologies, new regulations, and widespread prejudices that associated female brewsters with drunkenness and disorder. The taverns still use women to serve it, a low-status, low-skilled, and poorly remunerated tasks.<ref>{{cite book | last = Bennett | first = Judith M. | title = Ale, beer and brewsters in England: women's work in a changing world, 1300-1600 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = New York | year = 1999 | isbn = 9780195073904 }}</ref>
==Early modern period==
===Tudor era=== {{Further|Tudor period#Daily life in the period}}
[[File:Elizabeth I, Procession Portrait..jpg|thumb|250px|''The Procession Picture'', c. 1600, showing Elizabeth I borne along by her courtiers.]] While the Tudor era presents an abundance of material on the women of the nobility—especially royal wives and queens—historians have recovered scant documentation about the average lives of women. There has, however, been extensive statistical analysis of demographic and population data which includes women, especially in their childbearing roles.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Weinstein | first = Minna F. | title = Reconstructing our past: reflections on Tudor women | journal = International Journal of Women's Studies | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 133–158 | publisher = Eden Press Women's Publications | date = 1978 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=X2IpAAAAYAAJ | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>''On the social and demographic history see'': {{cite book | last = Palliser | first = D. M. | title = The age of Elizabeth: England under the later Tudors, 1547-1603 | publisher = Routledge | location = Oxfordshire, England New York, New York | year = 2013 | edition = 2nd | isbn = 9781315846750 }}</ref>
The role of women in society was, for the historical era, relatively unconstrained; Spanish and Italian visitors to England commented regularly, and sometimes caustically, on the freedom that women enjoyed in England, in contrast to their home cultures. England had more well-educated upper class women than was common anywhere in Europe.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Shapiro | first = Susan C. | title = Feminists in Elizabethan England | journal = [[History Today]] | volume = 27 | issue = 11 | pages = 703–711 | date = 1977 | url = http://www.historytoday.com/susan-c-shapiro/feminists-elizabethan-england | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Youings | first = Joyce A. | title = Sixteenth-century England | publisher = A. Lane | location = London | year = 1984 | isbn = 9780713912432 }}</ref>
The Queen's [[Elizabeth I of England#Marriage question|marital status]] was a major political and diplomatic topic. It also entered into the popular culture. Elizabeth's unmarried status inspired a cult of virginity. In poetry and portraiture, she was depicted as a virgin or a goddess or both, not as a normal woman.<ref>{{cite journal |author=John N. King |title=Queen Elizabeth I: Representations of the Virgin Queen |journal=[[Renaissance Quarterly]] |volume=43 |issue=1 |year=1990 |pages=30–74 |jstor=2861792 |doi=10.2307/2861792 }}</ref> Elizabeth made a virtue of her virginity: in 1559, she told the Commons, "And, in the end, this shall be for me sufficient, that a marble stone shall declare that a queen, having reigned such a time, lived and died a virgin".<ref>{{citation | last = Haigh | first = Christopher | contribution = The Queen and the throne | editor-last = Haigh | editor-first = Christopher | title = Elizabeth I | page = 23 | publisher = Longman | location = London New York | year = 1998 | edition = 2nd | isbn = 9780582437548 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Public tributes to the Virgin by 1578 acted as a coded assertion of opposition to the queen's marriage negotiations with the Duc d'Alençon.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Doran | first = Susan | title = Juno versus Diana: The treatment of Elizabeth I's marriage in plays and entertainments, 1561–1581 | journal = [[The Historical Journal]] | volume = 38 | issue = 2 | pages = 257–274 | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge Journals]] | doi = 10.1017/S0018246X00019427 | jstor = 2639984 | date = June 1995 | url = https://doi.org/10.1017/S0018246X00019427 | ref = harv | postscript = .| doi-broken-date = 2018-06-01 }}</ref>
In contrast to her father's emphasis on masculinity and physical prowess, Elizabeth emphasized the maternalism theme, saying often that she was married to her kingdom and subjects. She explained "I keep the good will of all my husbands — my good people — for if they did not rest assured of some special love towards them, they would not readily yield me such good obedience,"<ref>[[Agnes Strickland|Strickland, Agnes]] (1910), "[https://books.google.com/books?id=cF0NAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA424 Elizabeth]", in {{cite book | editor-last = Strickland | editor-first = Agnes | editor-link = Agnes Strickland | title = The life of Queen Elizabeth | page = 424 | publisher = J.M. Dent / E.P. Dutton | location = London / New York | year = 1910 | oclc = 1539139 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> and promised in 1563 they would never have a more natural mother than she.<ref>{{citation | last = Cowen Orlin | first = Lena | contribution = The fictional families of Elizabeth I | editor-last1 = Levin | editor-first1 = Carole | editor-last2 = Sullivan | editor-first2 = Patricia Ann | title = Political rhetoric, power, and Renaissance women | page = 90 | publisher = State University of New York Press | location = Albany | year = 1995 | isbn = 9780791425466 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Coch (1996) argues that her figurative motherhood played a central role in her complex self-representation, shaping and legitimating the personal rule of a divinely appointed female prince.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Coch | first = Christine | title = "Mother of my Contreye": Elizabeth I and Tudor construction of motherhood | journal = [[English Literary Renaissance]] | volume = 26 | issue = 3 | pages = 423–450 | publisher = [[University of Chicago Press]] | doi = 10.1111/j.1475-6757.1996.tb01506.x | jstor = 43447529 | date = Autumn 1996 | url = https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1475-6757.1996.tb01506.x | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
===Medical care=== Although medical men did not approve, women healers played a significant role in the medical care of Londoners from cradle to grave during the Elizabethan era. They were hired by parishes and hospitals, as well as by private families. They played central roles in the delivery of nursing care as well as medical, pharmaceutical, and surgical services throughout the city as part of organized systems of health care.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Harkness | first = Deborah E. | author-link = Deborah E. Harkness | title = A view from the streets: women and medical work in Elizabethan London | journal = [[Bulletin of the History of Medicine]] | volume = 82 | issue = 1 | pages = 52–85 | publisher = [[Johns Hopkins University]] | doi = 10.1353/bhm.2008.0001 | date = Spring 2008 | url = https://doi.org/10.1353/bhm.2008.0001 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Women's medical roles continue to expand in the 17th century, especially regarding care of paupers. They operated nursing homes for the homeless and sick poor, and also looked after abandoned and orphaned children, pregnant women, and lunatics. After 1700, the workhouse movement undermined many of these roles and the parish nurse became restricted largely to the rearing and nursing of children and infants.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Boulton | first = Jeremy | title = Welfare systems and the parish nurse in early modern London, 1650–1725 | journal = Family & Community History | volume = 10 | issue = 2 | pages = 127–151 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1179/175138107x234413 | date = 2007 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1179/175138107x234413 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
===Marriage=== Over ninety percent of English women (and adults, in general) entered marriage in this era at an average age of about [[Western European marriage pattern|25–26 years for the bride]] and 27–28 years for the groom.<ref>{{citation | last = Cressy | first = David | contribution = Holy matrimony | editor-last = Cressy | editor-first = David | title = Birth, marriage, and death: ritual, religion, and the life-cycle in Tudor and Stuart England | page = 285 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford England New York | year = 1997 | isbn = 9780198201687 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Among the nobility and gentry, the average was around 19-21 for brides and 24-26 for grooms.<ref>{{cite book | last = Young | first = Bruce W. | contribution = Family life in Shakespeare's world | editor-last = Young | editor-first = Bruce W. | title = Family life in the age of Shakespeare | page = 41 | publisher = Greenwood Press | location = Westport, Connecticut | year = 2009 | isbn = 9780313342394 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Many city and townswomen married for the first time in their thirties and forties and it was not unusual for orphaned young women to delay marriage until the late twenties or early thirties to help support their younger siblings,<ref>{{cite book | last = Greer | first = Germaine | author-link = Germaine Greer | title = Shakespeare's wife | publisher = Emblem Editions | location = Toronto | year = 2009 | isbn = 9780771035838 }}</ref> and roughly a fourth of all English brides were pregnant at their weddings.<ref>{{citation | last = Cressy | first = David | contribution = Childbed attendants | editor-last = Cressy | editor-first = David | title = Birth, marriage, and death: ritual, religion, and the life-cycle in Tudor and Stuart England | page = 74 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford England New York | year = 1997 | isbn = 9780198201687 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
===Witchcraft=== {{Further|Witch trials in early modern Scotland}} In England, Scotland, Wales, and Ireland there was a succession of [[Witchcraft Acts]] starting with Henry VIII's Act of 1542. They governed witchcraft and providing penalties for its practice, or—in 1735—rather for pretending to practise it.
In Wales, fear of witchcraft mounted around the year 1500. There was a growing alarm of women's magic as a weapon aimed against the state and church. The Church made greater efforts to enforce the canon law of marriage, especially in Wales where tradition allowed a wider range of sexual partnerships. There was a political dimension as well, as accusations of witchcraft were levied against the enemies of Henry VII, who was exerting more and more control over Wales.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Kamerick | first = Kathleen | title = Tanglost of Wales: magic and adultery in the Court of Chancery circa 1500 | journal = [[Sixteenth Century Journal]] | volume = 44 | issue = 1 | pages = 25–45 | publisher = [[Truman State University]] | date = Spring 2013 | url = https://www.escj.org/article/tanglost-wales-magic-and-adultery-court-chancery-circa-1500 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
The records of the Courts of Great Sessions for Wales, 1536-1736 show that Welsh custom was more important than English law. Custom provided a framework of responding to witches and witchcraft in such a way that interpersonal and communal harmony was maintained, Showing to regard to the importance of honour, social place and cultural status. Even when found guilty, execution did not occur.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Parkin | first = Sally | title = Witchcraft, women's honour and customary law in early modern Wales | journal = [[Social History (journal)|Social History]] | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 295–318 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/03071020600746636 | jstor = 4287362 | date = August 2006 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/03071020600746636 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
Becoming king in 1603, [[James I]] brought to England and Scotland continental explanations of witchcraft. He set out the much stiffer [[Witchcraft Acts|Witchcraft Act of 1604]], which made it a felony under common law. One goal was to divert suspicion away from male homosociality among the elite, and focus fear on female communities and large gatherings of women. He thought they threatened his political power so he laid the foundation for witchcraft and occultism policies, especially in Scotland. The point was that a widespread belief in the conspiracy of witches and a witches' Sabbath with the devil deprived women of political influence.
